thread.title: November 2015 election: Vote, learn about issues (FAQs)
thread.title_full: November 2015 election: Vote, learn about issues (FAQs)

author: Michelle Brence | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: November 2015 election: Vote, learn about issues (FAQs)
text:
Here's what you need to know to vote in next month's special election, Nov. 3, 2015. 
Am I registered to vote? Check or update your status on the Secretary of State's website . 
How can I register? It's too late for this election; Oct. 13 was the deadline. You can still register for upcoming elections, though, online at the Secretary of State's Office website or in person at your county elections office. Here's where to go in the Portland area: Multnomah County Elections Division: 1040 S.E. Morrison St. Washington County Elections: 3700 S.W. Murray Blvd. Suite 101, Beaverton. Clackamas County Elections: 1710 Red Soils Court, Suite 100, Oregon City. 
Receiving a ballot: Ballots were mailed starting Oct. 14. 
Voting deadline: Ballots must be received at your county elections office by 8 p.m. Nov. 3 by mail or at a drop box. 
Where can I find a drop box? Multnomah County: Elections Division, 1040 S.E. Morrison St.; any county library; Pioneer Courthouse Square; and other sites. Find a complete list. Washington County: Elections office, 3700 S.W. Murray Blvd. Suite 101, Beaverton. Many libraries and city halls also have drop boxes. Find a complete list. Clackamas County: Elections Division, 1710 Red Soils Court, Suite 100, Oregon City; and at many libraries and city halls. Find a complete list. Statewide: Find the Secretary of State's Office statewide locating tool. 
Make sure your ballot is counted: Multnomah County is offering a pilot program to allow voters to receive alerts when ballots are mailed, received, and accepted or rejected. Voters can fix ballots with signature issues to make sure they're counted. Sign up to participate in the free-of-charge program. 
What's on the ballot? Washington County voters will decide on public-safety and library levies, Troutdale will vote on a gas tax, and Gladstone voters will decide on ponying up money for a new city hall and police station. Find a full rundown of issues on local ballots and highlights from around the region. 
More coverage: Visit oregonlive.com/elections for stories. We'll have results on election night at oregonlive.com. 
Michelle Brence
